Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 52024-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
May 2018 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: The Midterm Review of 
the 13th Five-Year Plan and the Initial Research 
Towards the 14th Five-Year Plan 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011. 
 The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in 
conducting the midterm review of the 13th Five-Year Plan (13th plan) and the preparation of the 
14th Five-Year Plan (14th plan).1 This is a continuation of the support that the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) provided to the 12th and 13th plans. The TA is included in the country operations 
business plan, 2018–2020 for the PRC.2 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the NDRC agreed on (i) the objective of the 
study, which is to help the PRC achieve higher quality growth to address the people's ever-
growing needs for a better life; (ii) the key areas to be covered—people-centered urbanization, 
demographic transition, and ecological civilization; and (iii) the major milestones—submission of 
the draft midterm review in June 2018 and provision of strategic recommendations for the 14th 
plan in June 2019.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The economic performance of the PRC since 1978 has been impressive. Gross domestic 
product growth has averaged about 9.6% per year and per capita income has increased by a 
factor of 8.5. Rapid economic growth has led to significant improvements in human well-being 
and quality of life. During 1978–2016, the PRC’s rural poverty headcount ratio declined from 
97.5% to 4.5%,3 life expectancy at birth increased from 67 to 73 years, and child mortality declined 
from 65 deaths per 1,000 live births to 18 per 1,000. 
 
4.  Historically, the PRC has been very successful in achieving its income-based policy 
targets. However, robust economic growth has come at a cost, notably environmental degradation 
and pollution, uneven distribution of development benefits leading to inequality, and a variety of 
social challenges associated with regional and rural–urban disparities and an aging population. 
Accordingly, since 2002, the PRC has been progressively shifting from a singular focus on 
economic  growth  to  a  broader  concept  of  quality  development,  encompassing  social 
inclusiveness (“harmonious society”) and environmental sustainability (“ecological civilization”). 
The government reinforced this trend in the policies of the 13th plan and more recently in the 
report of the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of the People’s Republic of China, 
which emphasized a new strategic goal to foster the “well-being” (mei hao sheng huo) of the 
people. This will be a top priority for the government in the coming years. 
 
5.  The PRC has a long tradition of formulating five-year plans to address the country’s 
development challenges and promote social and economic development. The plans lay out the 
strategic  objectives  of the  country,  establish the  government’s  work  priorities,  and  provide 
guidance for market activities. Since the founding of the PRC, the government has formulated 13 
five-year plans, each of which has had a significant impact on the country’s development. ADB 
provided  strategic  advice  through  TA  projects  for  both  the  12th  and  13th  plans.  The 
implementation of the 13th plan is ongoing and close to midterm. The government plans to start 
the midterm review of the 13th plan in June 2018. Then, drawing on the review’s findings and 
conclusions, it intends to start preparing the 14th plan, which will cover 2021–2025. This will be a 
critical period for the PRC as it aims to move beyond the current goal of a “moderately prosperous” 
                                                
1 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 April 2018. 
2 ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2018–2020. Manila. 
3 The current rural poverty standard is CNY2,300 (in 2010 constant prices) per person per year. China Statistics Press. 
  2017. China Statistical Yearbook 2017. Beijing. ADB recognizes this member as the People’s Republic of China.

2 
society  and  transition  toward  a  high-income  economy  and  a  modern  society  focused  on 
developing the broader well-being of the population. 
 
6.  The NDRC and ADB jointly identified and selected three substudies for the TA that are 
highly relevant to the broader well-being of the population. 
(i)  People-centered and environmentally sustainable urbanization. The substudy 
will focus on issues in these areas: (a) low-carbon and climate-resilient urban 
development;  (b)  city-cluster  and  urban–rural  development  cooperation  and 
partnerships; and (c) social inclusion, covering issues of the social protection 
design and accessibility to social protection benefits and basic public services, 
making cities healthier, and the migrant-related aspects of these challenges. 
(ii)  Demographic transition. The substudy will cover the following issues: (a) trends 
and characteristics of demographic transition; (b) family planning policies and 
services, including the two-child policy, reproductive health for mothers, and others 
that respond to the needs of families following the policies; (c) health and education 
services for infants and young children; (d) and other salient demographic issues 
including  the  skewed  birth  ratio,  regional  and  urban–rural  distributions  of 
population, and migration. 
(iii)  Ecological civilization. The substudy will build on past and ongoing ADB work, 
and  international  best  practices  to  recommend  necessary  policy  reforms  for 
environmental protection (air, water, and soil pollution control), ecosystem and 
natural resources management, and environmental regulation and administration. 
 
7.   Each of the substudies will consider three dimensions of the policy challenge in their 
respective areas—governance and institutional reforms, financial mechanisms and resources, 
and economic instruments and incentives. 
 
8.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. During the first phase, the project team will 
conduct a midterm review of the 13th plan in several key areas. Through this review, the team 
will assess progress against the objectives of the 13th plan on the effectiveness of the policy 
changes and the institutional and/or legal reforms implemented, and the remaining challenges to 
achieving the 13th plan’s goals, including those posed by domestic and global socioeconomic 
trends. 
 
9.  The second phase of the TA will build on the findings and conclusions of the midterm 
review and carry out research in the three selected areas to provide inputs for the preparation of 
the 14th plan. The project team will draw on international experience in formulating its analysis 
and recommendations. The proposed reforms will be sequenced and linked to a central theme of 
transitioning to higher quality development in the pursuit of national well-being. To this end, as 
part of the second phase, the team will develop an overarching central theme for the study that 
will be discussed and agreed upon once the government’s priorities for the 14th plan are more 
firmly established. The project team will prepare an overview report that will summarize the 
findings, conclusions, and policy recommendations under the overarching central theme. 
 
10.  To facilitate the transition from the midterm review of the 13th plan to the initial research 
for the 14th plan, and to better define the overarching central theme for the study, the government 
and ADB agree to convene a high-level academic conference in the second half of 2018. The 
conference will involve senior PRC government officials, eminent international experts, and 
celebrated national specialists. These participants will (i) comment on the midterm review of the 
13th Plan, (ii) discuss the latest thinking on new models of progress and how the PRC may apply 
these to its long term-strategy, and (iii) some of the international and national experts will be

3 
commissioned to write a series of papers for the conference that could provide the intellectual 
underpinnings for the study for the 14th plan.4 The conference would aim to draw experts from 
the PRC, ADB, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the United Kingdom, 
the United States, and others. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: progress towards well-being (mei hao sheng 
huo) goal improved.5 The TA will contribute to the following outcome: policy and regulatory 
environment to support balanced and sustainable development improved.6 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
12.  Output 1: One main report and three subreports for each phase prepared.  The TA 
project team will provide two sets of reports. The first set will be the 13th plan midterm review 
report on the three selected areas. ADB will submit the draft midterm review report to the NDRC 
in June 2018 and its final version in September 2018. The second set of reports will consist of a 
comprehensive overview report and three subreports with policy recommendations for the 14th 
plan on the selected areas. ADB will submit the draft report to the NDRC in June 2019 and the 
final report in October 2019. The second phase of the TA will seek to build on the outcome of the 
review workshops of the first phase and the high-level conference to prepare the final study 
containing the recommendations for the 14th plan. This is likely to require further research and 
engagement with domestic academic institutions.  
 
13.  Output  2:  Awareness  of  balanced  and  sustainable  development  among 
stakeholders enhanced. The TA will start with a series of workshops that will provide inputs into 
two products: (i) an interim set of reports that will provide inputs into the midterm review of the 
13th plan (June 2018); and (ii) a high-level academic conference on the central theme of the 
PRC’s transition to a focus on well-being and higher quality of development (August 2018).  At 
least 150 participants (of which at least 30% are women) will attend the above-mentioned 
workshops  and  conference  with  increased  understanding  on  balanced  and  sustainable 
development including gender equality. The final versions of the two sets of reports will be printed 
for distribution in the conferences and dissemination activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000 of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. The value of government 
contribution is estimated to account for 14% of the total TA cost. 
                                                
4 This model was used in the 2010 Cairncross Foundation study “Medium and Long-Term Development and 
Transformation of the Chinese Economy” headed by Edwin Lim and Michael Spence. 
5 Communist Party of the People’s Republic of China. 2017. The Report of the 19th National Congress of the 
Communist Party of the People’s Republic of China. Beijing. 
6 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and work 
closely with the consultants to produce the envisioned outputs. ADB will use the One-ADB 
approach  to  support  this  process  through  a  flagship  study  using  ADB-wide  expertise  and 
resources. ADB will set up a steering committee led by the director general of the East Asia 
Department, comprising members from the East Asia Department, the Economic Research and 
Regional  Cooperation Department,  and  the  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department. The steering committee will guide the consultants and review the reports at various 
maturity stages. The Department of Development Planning, NDRC will be the executing and 
implementing agency. The Department of Development Planning, NDRC will be responsible for 
(i) coordinating with relevant government agencies for guidance on the studies, (ii) carrying out 
day-to-day  TA  activities  such  as  providing  the  TA  project  team  with  updated  policies  and 
overseeing the team’s research work, (iii) supporting the TA project team to hold TA review 
workshops and organize a conference for output dissemination and knowledge sharing, and (iv) 
reviewing and commenting on the draft reports prepared by the ADB TA project team at various 
stages. 
17.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

with items 2.9.2 and 2.10.2 of ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Action Plan. Manila. 
Source: ADB. 
 
18.  Consulting services. The TA will finance a total of 45 person-months of consulting 
services (11 international consultants for a total of 22 person-months and 8 national consultants 
for a total of 23 person-months).7 ADB will engage the consultants following with the ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
                                                
7  The TA will be complemented by resources provided under other TA projects including: ADB. 2016. Technical 
Assistance for Scaling Up Private Sector Participation and Use of Market-Based Approaches for Environmental 
Management. Manila; ADB. 2017.Technical Assistance for Promoting Low-Carbon Development in Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Program Cities. Manila; ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance for Country Diagnostic 
Studies in Selected Developing Member Countries (Subproject 4). Manila; and ADB  staff supported by staff 
consultants. In total, an additional 39.5 person-months of consulting services financed from these sources are 
expected to contribute to the Midterm Review of the 13th plan and the Initial Research Towards the 14th plan.

5 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. All consultants will be engaged using the 
individual consultant selection method.8 In line with the action plan for the Midterm Review of 
Strategy  2020,9 lump-sum  payments  and/or  output-based  contracts  may  be  offered.  The 
consultants will submit progress reports, which will be reviewed by ADB and the Department of 
Development Planning, NDRC. The government and ADB may invite resource persons to review 
the consultants’ outputs and share knowledge during workshops and conferences. 
 
19.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  following  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
20.  The  government  and  ADB  will  disseminate  the  TA  results  through  project  reports, 
workshops, and media releases. The TA project team will develop a knowledge product, and ADB 
and  the  NDRC  will  distribute  electronic  copies.  The government  and ADB  will  organize  a 
conference to disseminate the TA outputs and will serve as a knowledge-sharing event. The target 
participants will include government officials and national and international experts. Evaluation of 
the TA outcome will follow ADB guidelines and will be provided to the Department of Development 
Planning, NDRC. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for The Midterm Review of the 13th Five-Year 
Plan and the Initial Research Towards the 14th Five-Year Plan, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
 
                                                
8  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
9  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Action Plan. Manila.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. One main report and three subreports for each phase prepared 
1.1 Prepare draft midterm review reports of the 13th Five-Year Plan by June 2018. 
1.2 Prepare final midterm review reports of the 13th Five-Year Plan by September 2018. 
1.3 Finish draft reports supporting the preparation of the 14th Five-Year Plan by June 2019. 
1.4 Finish final reports supporting the preparation of the 14th Five-Year Plan by October 2019. 
 
2.  Awareness of balanced and sustainable development among stakeholders enhanced 
2.1 Conduct three technical workshops on the 13th Five-Year Plan by May 2018. 
2.2 Conduct high-level conference on well-being by August 2018. 
2.3 Conduct final review workshop for the midterm review report of the 13th Five-Year Plan by December 
2018. 
2.4 Conduct three technical workshops on preparing the 14th Five-Year Plan by June 2019. 
2.5 Conduct final review workshop on preparing the 14th Five-Year Plan by November 2019. 
2.6 Organize dissemination events after submission of the final midterm review report of the 13th Five-Year 
Plan by December 2018. 
2.7 Organize dissemination events after submission of the final report supporting the preparation of the 14th 
Five-Year Plan by December 2019. 
2.8 Distribute TA findings and policy recommendations by December 2019.
